metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Cosmic-ray observation system of soil moisture of Sidaoqiao Superstation, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a Cosmic-ray Soil Moisture Observing System of soil moisture of Sidaoqiao Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2019. The site (101.1374° E, 42.0012° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 873 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, C), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour), thermal neutron counts (N2C, counts per hour), sample time of fast neutrons (N1ET, s), and sample time of thermal neutrons (N2ET, s). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

background: The acquisition of regional surface soil moisture has long been a research challenge. In recent years, the use of cosmic ray fast neutron methods to measure regional surface soil moisture has made significant progress. As a novel medium-scale non-destructive measurement method for soil moisture, the cosmic ray fast neutron method can obtain soil moisture within a source area of approximately 300 meters in radius. This larger measurement area fills the gap between traditional point observations and remote sensing large-area observations. Traditional measurement methods include: gravimetric method (oven-drying method), neutron gauge method, capacitance method, tensiometer method, time-domain reflectometry (TDR), and frequency-domain reflectometry (FDR). These measurement methods are all destructive and point-based, with measurement scales mostly at small scales, poor spatial representativeness, and difficulty in obtaining information on the regional distribution of soil moisture. The feasibility study of remote sensing monitoring of soil moisture began in the 1960s, with applied research starting in the mid-1970s. Remote sensing technology can achieve rapid and large-area soil moisture monitoring, but the soil moisture obtained through remote sensing is an average value at the pixel scale, with spatial resolutions generally ranging from tens of meters (aerial remote sensing) to tens of kilometers (satellite remote sensing), and it only provides instantaneous values at the time of aircraft or satellite overpass, limiting the application of large-scale remote sensing measurements in practical soil moisture monitoring. There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing monitoring, which is the inability to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating remote sensing-derived soil moisture, it is not possible to obtain the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. In recent years, research on measuring surface soil moisture using cosmic ray fast neutrons has gradually attracted attention. The intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the surface is inversely related to soil moisture content. By setting up a neutron probe above the surface to measure the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons, surface soil moisture content can be inferred. The cosmic ray fast neutron method is a passive, non-invasive medium-scale soil moisture measurement method, with a measurement radius of about 300 meters and an effective measurement depth of 12 to 76 cm.
research objective: This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the agricultural fields of the Zhangye region in the middle reaches of the Heihe River, and compares the results with data from Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN) to analyze the reliability of cosmic ray observations. The article analyzes the results of regional soil moisture observation experiments conducted in the Zhangye oasis agricultural fields, indicating that the cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content. It not only accurately captures long-term time series soil moisture at the agricultural scale but also provides meaningful ground validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture.
challenges: There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale monitoring through remote sensing, which makes it difficult to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating soil moisture retrieved from remote sensing, it is challenging to acquire the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. Hydrogen atoms in the cosmic ray source region are not only present in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. The presence of these hydrogen atom sources inevitably affects the propagation of fast neutrons. Zreda et al. pointed out that the presence of lattice water reduces the detection depth of cosmic rays; however, under the assumption that lattice water and soil organic matter remain constant, these effects can be eliminated through in-situ soil moisture calibration of the source region. In sparsely vegetated areas, the influence of vegetation can also be eliminated based on in-situ soil moisture calibration, but under rapidly growing vegetation, the moisture content of the vegetation has a certain impact on observations, and there is currently no comprehensive method to correct for this. The presence of water vapor affects the measurement source region of cosmic rays, and MCNPX simulations indicate that the detection radius under saturated water vapor is about 10% lower than that under dry air.
methods: The dataset used in this article comes from the 2012 "Heihe River Basin Eco-Hydrological Comprehensive Remote Sensing Observation Experiment," which mainly includes cosmic ray soil moisture datasets, wireless sensor network datasets (Soil-NET part), and rainfall datasets (Daman Station). During soil moisture observation, only a fast neutron probe needs to be installed; at the beginning of this experiment, only one fast neutron probe was installed for soil moisture observation. This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye area in the middle reaches of the Heihe River and compares it with soil moisture wireless sensor network data (Wireless Sensor Network, WSN) to study the reliability of the cosmic ray observation results.
dataset: The cosmic ray soil moisture dataset mainly includes raw fast neutron data, raw atmospheric pressure data, etc., with a sampling frequency of 1 hour. Fast neutron data can be used to infer soil moisture information in the study area. SoilNET mainly contains observation data from 50 SoilNET soil moisture/temperature nodes located within the MODIS pixel of the Daman Super Station. Each node can connect to 4 SISOMOP (Simple Soil Moisture Probe) soil moisture/temperature probes, which measure soil moisture and temperature at depths of 4, 10, 20, and 40 cm, with 19 of them distributed within the cosmic ray source area. The sampling frequency of SoilNET nodes is 10 minutes. This study primarily uses SoilNET node soil moisture data to validate cosmic ray observation results, requiring the aggregation of the original 10-minute data into 1-hour data for synchronization with cosmic ray data. The rainfall dataset (Daman Super Station) mainly contains raw rainfall data, with a sampling frequency of 10 minutes. During use, the original data needs to be aggregated into 1-hour data to analyze the relationship between cosmic ray soil moisture changes and rainfall.
findings: The cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content, not only accurately capturing long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also providing meaningful surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture. Comparisons show that cosmic rays reflect a surface-level change in soil moisture, which can effectively indicate the trend of soil moisture changes beneath the farmland surface. After excluding data from the irrigation period, the correlation coefficient significantly increased to 0.86, and the RMSE decreased to 0.028 m³/m³.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure regional surface soil moisture in arid regions?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to measure regional surface soil moisture in arid regions is the cosmic-ray neutron method. This method involves using a neutron probe placed above the surface to measure the intensity of cosmic-ray fast neutrons, which are inversely related to soil moisture content. The method provides a measurement radius of around 300 meters and an effective depth of 12 to 76 cm, allowing for non-invasive, mesoscale soil moisture measurement.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that includes observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset comprises long-term observational data from both artificial and natural oasis-desert systems, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These observations are typically gathered using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, with additional data from automatic weather stations and groundwater table measurements.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge associated with measuring soil moisture using traditional point measurement and remote sensing methods in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge associated with measuring soil moisture using traditional point measurement and remote sensing methods is the gap in obtaining regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmlands or small watersheds. Traditional point measurement methods, like gravimetric and neutron probe techniques, often lack spatial representation, while remote sensing provides pixel-scale averages that are limited to the specific moment when the aircraft or satellite passes over, restricting continuous data acquisition.

Definition.Question: What is the 'cosmic ray fast neutron method' in the context of soil moisture measurement?
Definition.Answer: The 'cosmic ray fast neutron method' is a novel, non-invasive medium-scale soil moisture measurement technique that can cover an area with a radius of approximately 300 meters. It fills the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing observations. The method involves measuring the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the soil surface using a neutron probe, from which the soil moisture content can be inferred. This method is passive, and non-intrusive, and effectively captures regional soil moisture data.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement compare to traditional point measurement methods like TDR and FDR in terms of spatial representation and measurement scale?
Comparison.Answer: The cosmic-ray neutron probe method offers a non-invasive, medium-scale measurement capability with a measurement radius of approximately 300 meters, effectively bridging the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Traditional methods such as TDR and FDR are point-based, invasive, and provide small-scale measurements with poor spatial representation. The cosmic-ray method allows for regional soil moisture information and fills the gap between point and remote sensing measurements.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced in measuring soil moisture using cosmic-ray neutron probes differ from those encountered in remote sensing soil moisture methods?
Comparison.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron probes face challenges such as accounting for hydrogen atoms in vegetation, soil organic matter, and atmospheric water vapor, which can affect neutron propagation and measurement accuracy. These influences require field calibration to mitigate. Remote sensing methods, on the other hand, provide pixel-scale average values and are limited by temporal resolution, offering only instantaneous measurements when satellites or aircraft pass over. Remote sensing cannot provide continuous data and lacks the medium-scale measurement capacity of cosmic-ray probes.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about ecological stability and socioeconomic development in oasis–desert areas from long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data collected over a decade?
Interpretation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. Long-term observations help in achieving goals such as carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development in these areas.

Interpretation.Question: How can cosmic-ray neutron data improve the accuracy of soil moisture monitoring in arid regions compared to traditional methods and remote sensing approaches?
Interpretation.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron methods provide a non-invasive means to measure soil moisture over a larger area, filling the gap between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. This approach offers spatially representative data, which can enhance the validation of remote sensing soil moisture retrievals and provide reliable long-term soil moisture trends at farm or watershed scales.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the presence of hydrogen atoms from various sources, such as vegetation or water vapor, affect the reliability of cosmic-ray neutron measurements for soil moisture, and what calibration techniques can mitigate these effects?
Interpretation.Answer: Hydrogen atoms from sources like vegetation, water vapor, and soil organic matter can influence neutron propagation, potentially affecting measurement accuracy. Calibration techniques involving field soil moisture corrections can mitigate these effects, though challenges remain, particularly with rapidly growing vegetation and varying water vapor conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in measuring regional soil moisture using traditional methods, prompting the use of cosmic ray neutron techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional methods like weighing, neutron probe, and TDR are destructive and point-based, offering limited spatial representation. They fail to capture regional distribution of soil moisture, especially at the scale between point measurements and large remote sensing areas. Cosmic ray neutron techniques provide a non-invasive, intermediate scale measurement option, addressing these challenges by filling the gap between traditional point measurements and remote sensing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for pressure correction in cosmic ray neutron data when calculating soil moisture content?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Pressure correction is necessary because the intensity of fast neutrons detected by cosmic ray instruments is influenced by atmospheric pressure. The correction ensures that variations in pressure do not skew the neutron counts, which are inversely related to soil moisture content. This correction helps in obtaining accurate soil moisture measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using cosmic-ray neutron sensing for measuring soil moisture in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using cosmic-ray neutron sensing allows for non-invasive, mid-scale soil moisture measurement, effectively filling the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. It can provide continuous long-term data critical for understanding regional soil moisture dynamics, which is particularly valuable in arid regions where soil moisture is a key factor in ecological and agricultural stability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating cosmic-ray neutron data with wireless sensor networks for soil moisture monitoring?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating cosmic-ray neutron data with wireless sensor networks can enhance the reliability and accuracy of soil moisture monitoring. This combination allows for cross-validation of data, providing a comprehensive understanding of soil moisture dynamics over time and space, and offering ground-truth data for validating remote sensing models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance is vital for achieving sustainable oasis development, supporting the ecological security, and ensuring the socioeconomic development of these regions. A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for recognizing interactions between these systems, which play a significant role in maintaining ecological stability and contribute to carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which are crucial for ensuring sustainable development and ecological security. Long-term datasets help in recognizing oasis–desert interactions, addressing challenges such as ecological degradation, and supporting the achievement of carbon peaking and neutrality goals by providing essential data for protecting ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are used to process and correct fast neutron data from a cosmic ray instrument for soil moisture measurement?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing procedures for fast neutron data include several steps. First, data screening is performed based on four criteria: eliminating data with voltage less than or equal to 11.8 volts, relative humidity greater than or equal to 80%, sampling intervals not within 60±1 minutes, and fast neutron counts with fluctuations greater than 200 from the previous or next hour. Next, a pressure correction is applied to the raw data using a neutron pressure correction formula provided in the instrument manual. Finally, instrument calibration is conducted to determine N0, the fast neutron count under dry soil conditions, which is used for calculating soil moisture.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are cosmic ray instruments set up and calibrated to continuously monitor soil moisture in an arid region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To set up cosmic ray instruments for soil moisture monitoring, a single fast neutron probe is installed above the soil surface, typically at a height of 0.5m. Calibration of the instrument involves determining N0, the fast neutron count under dry soil conditions, which can be calculated by comparing the measured soil moisture or using dense soil moisture sensors. Calibration helps ensure accurate soil moisture calculation from the cosmic ray instrument's neutron data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the reliability and accuracy of soil moisture data collected using cosmic ray instruments in varying environmental conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure reliability and accuracy, the cosmic ray soil moisture measurement system involves comparing its data with other soil moisture measurement methods like wireless sensor networks. Additionally, corrections for environmental factors such as pressure and humidity are applied to the data. The presence of hydrogen atoms in other materials like lattice water, organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor is considered during data analysis, and adjustments are made based on calibration against ground truth soil moisture data.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the use of cosmic ray neutron methods for measuring soil moisture in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The cosmic ray neutron method has emerged as a novel mesoscale soil moisture measurement technique that leverages the relationship between the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the soil surface and soil moisture content. This method fills the gap between small-scale point measurements and large-scale remote sensing, providing data across a measurement radius of approximately 300 meters with an effective depth of 12 to 76 cm. It is a passive, non-intrusive method that allows for the acquisition of soil moisture data over a significant area, which traditional methods cannot achieve effectively.

Enablement.Question: What challenges and solutions are associated with using cosmic ray neutron methods to measure soil moisture, considering factors like vegetation and atmospheric conditions?
Enablement.Answer: One of the challenges in using cosmic ray neutron methods for measuring soil moisture is the presence of hydrogen atoms not only in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect fast neutron propagation. These factors can influence measurement accuracy. Solutions include performing in-situ soil moisture calibration to account for constant sources like lattice water and soil organic matter, and adjusting for vegetation effects in sparsely vegetated areas. However, rapidly growing vegetation and water vapor still present challenges, as there are currently no comprehensive correction methods for these variables.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving accurate soil moisture measurements using cosmic-ray neutron sensors in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensors measure soil moisture based on the intensity of fast neutrons, which are influenced by hydrogen atoms not only in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. These additional hydrogen sources can affect neutron propagation, leading to challenges in accurate measurements. For example, lattice water can reduce the detection depth of cosmic-ray sensors, and vegetation water content can affect observations, especially during rapid plant growth phases, for which there are currently no comprehensive correction methods.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that long-term observational data of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems are crucial for sustainable development?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are essential to quantitatively understand the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is critical for achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals, protecting ecological stability, and ensuring the sustainable socioeconomic development of oases, which are key ecological and economic hubs in arid and semi-arid regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional measurement methods for soil moisture be inadequate for capturing regional distribution in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional soil moisture measurement methods, such as weighing, neutron probe, and time-domain reflectometry, are typically small-scale, point-based, and invasive, which limits their spatial representativeness and ability to capture regional soil moisture distribution. These methods cannot easily provide the required data for small watersheds or farmland-scale observations, creating a gap between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing capabilities. Cosmic-ray neutron sensors, however, offer a non-invasive, mesoscale alternative with a measurement radius of approximately 300 meters, addressing this gap.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using cosmic-ray neutron instrumentation for soil moisture measurements in arid regions, and how might these affect data reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron instrumentation for soil moisture measurements can be affected by various hydrogen sources such as soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can impact the propagation of fast neutrons. These influences can introduce uncertainties in soil moisture measurements, especially in areas with rapidly growing vegetation or significant atmospheric water vapor. Calibration using local soil samples can mitigate some of these effects, but challenges remain in dynamically correcting for vegetation changes and atmospheric conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how cosmic-ray neutron sensing can accurately measure regional soil moisture despite interference from hydrogen atoms in various sources.
Assertion.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensing is a passive, non-invasive method that measures the intensity of fast neutrons above the soil surface, which is inversely proportional to soil moisture content. This technique fills the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Interference from hydrogen atoms in other sources like lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor can affect the measurement. However, these influences can be corrected through field calibration of soil moisture in the source area. In sparse vegetation areas, corrections based on in-situ soil moisture calibration can mitigate vegetation effects, but rapidly growing vegetation still poses a challenge.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the key data collection techniques used for measuring soil moisture in arid and semiarid regions, emphasizing the role of cosmic-ray neutron sensors.
Request/Directive.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron sensors are used as a non-invasive, mid-scale soil moisture measurement technique capable of capturing soil moisture within a radius of approximately 300 meters and an effective depth of 12-76 cm. This approach bridges the gap between traditional point-based measurements and remote sensing measurements by providing spatially representative data in regions where traditional methods fall short. Data from cosmic-ray sensors are complemented and validated using Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN) and other conventional methods, such as frequency domain reflectometry (FDR) and time-domain reflectometry (TDR), to ensure reliability and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges encountered in collecting and validating soil moisture data using cosmic-ray neutron sensors in oasis-desert systems and propose potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for soil moisture data collection include the presence of hydrogen atoms in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect the propagation of fast neutrons. This interference can lead to inaccuracies in soil moisture measurements. To mitigate these challenges, field calibration of soil moisture using in-situ samples is essential to account for these factors. Additionally, in sparse vegetation areas, the influence of vegetation can be corrected through calibration, although fast-growing vegetation presents unresolved challenges. Simulation studies suggest that water vapor reduces the detection radius of cosmic-ray sensors, indicating a need for further research into atmospheric conditions' impact on measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and evaluate potential datasets that can be integrated with cosmic-ray neutron data to enhance the understanding of soil moisture dynamics in oasis-desert environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that can be integrated with cosmic-ray neutron data include those from Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN), which provide soil moisture and temperature data at various depths (e.g., 4, 10, 20, and 40 cm). These datasets can offer temporal resolution and spatial accuracy that complement cosmic-ray neutron measurements. Additionally, integrating hydrometeorological data such as precipitation, air pressure, and soil temperature profiles from automatic weather stations can provide a comprehensive view of environmental factors affecting soil moisture dynamics. By aggregating these datasets, researchers can enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of soil moisture observations, providing a robust framework for validating remote sensing data and improving soil moisture modeling in oasis-desert systems.
